title: 2.2 – Common Networking Hardware (CompTIA A+ 220-1101)
content:
🧰 2.2 – Common Networking Hardware (CompTIA A+ 220-1101)

🌐 Routers

Connects multiple networks together (usually LAN to the Internet)
Assigns IP addresses via DHCP
Provides NAT and firewall features

🧠 Exam Tip: Routers operate at Layer 3 (Network) of the OSI model.

🔀 Switches

Connect devices within a LAN
Uses MAC addresses to forward traffic efficiently

▪️ Managed Switch

Can be configured (VLANs, QoS, port control). Used in larger or business networks.

▪️ Unmanaged Switch

Plug-and-play, no configuration. Used in homes or small offices.

🧠 Exam Tip: Switches = Layer 2, unless it's a Layer 3 switch, which routes too.

📶 Access Points

Extends Wi-Fi coverage. Acts as a bridge between wired and wireless.

🧠 Exam Tip: Not the same as a router, but often built-in.

🧵 Patch Panel

Central point for cable organization. No intelligence—just physical connection points.

Used in network racks for easy cable management.

🧠 Tip: Think of it as the network’s “phonebook” for cables.

🔥 Firewall

Filters incoming/outgoing traffic based on rules. Can be software or hardware. Protects against unauthorized access.

🧠 Exam Tip: Look for scenarios involving port blocking, IP filtering, or packet inspection.

⚡ Power over Ethernet (PoE)

Sends power + data through Ethernet cable.

▪️ Injectors

Add power to Ethernet lines for non-PoE switches.

▪️ PoE Switch

Built-in power delivery, no injector needed.

▪️ PoE Standards

  • IEEE 802.3af (PoE) = 15.4W
  • IEEE 802.3at (PoE+) = 25.5W

🧠 Tip: Used for powering APs, IP cameras, VoIP phones.

🧩 Hub

Repeats all network traffic to all ports (no intelligence). Causes network collisions (uses CSMA/CD).

Obsolete, replaced by switches.

🧠 Exam Tip: If it floods traffic → it’s a hub, not a switch.

📡 Cable Modem

Connects to ISP via coaxial cable. Converts signal for Internet use (DOCSIS standard).

🧠 Tip: Common in home internet setups.

☎️ DSL (Digital Subscriber Line)

Uses telephone lines for internet. Slower than cable/fiber.

🧠 Tip: Often found in rural areas.

🔦 ONT (Optical Network Terminal)

Device that converts fiber signals to Ethernet. Used in FTTH (Fiber to the Home) installations.

🧠 Tip: If the scenario includes fiber, look for ONT.

💻 NIC (Network Interface Card)

Hardware that connects a device to a network. Can be wired (Ethernet) or wireless (Wi-Fi).

🧠 Tip: Found inside computers, printers, etc.

🧠 SDN (Software-Defined Networking)

Controls network via software, not hardware. Used in cloud networks and datacenters.

Centralized controller dynamically manages traffic.

🧠 Tip: Flexible, programmable—modern enterprise networks love SDN.

✅ Final Tips

  • Switch = efficient, Hub = dumb
  • Router = connects networks, AP = connects devices to Wi-Fi
  • Patch panel = organizes cables, PoE = powers devices
  • Know which protocols/services each hardware type supports!
